requirements:
Program Overview

POSITION OVERVIEW Position Title DHA-Interpretation Research Development NPS Unit Name Salem Maritime and Saugus Iron Works National Historic Sites Position Dates May 10,2021-July 31,2021 DHA The DHA Resource Assistant internship (DHA-RA) is a unique internship opportunity within the Department of the Interior (DOI). The objective is to build a pathway to employment in the DOI for exemplary students in higher education. DHA-RA interns will apply content expertise to NPS management and build a network with federal employees throughout the internship. These rigorous internships require specialized expertise and typically are available to upper-level undergraduate or graduate students or recent graduates. The internships are designed to develop the participant's technical and creative thinking abilities, leadership skills, and problem-solving capabilities. Successful completion of the internship does not guarantee that the participant will be hired into a federal position.
To be eligible for a DHA--RA Internship, applicants must be a U.S. citizen or U.S. permanent legal resident ("green-card-holder”) and enrolled or within one year of graduating from an institution of higher education.
DHA-RA interns who successfully complete the internship requirements become eligible for two years from the date of their degree to be non-competitively hired by the Department of Interior. Position Description The rich history of African American people, cultures, and communities in Essex County,Massachusetts runs deep. This history is embedded in the cultural landscape, fromcemeteries to a renamed park in honor of two famed 19th century black abolitionists. EssexCounty residents, archivists, educators, interpreters, historians, and scholars alike have beenworking to unearth this history and recover these fascinating stories in order to provide afuller account of the county's past and present. In a span of nearly four hundred years, Blackpeople have shaped and been shaped by Essex County. However, real challenges, historicand contemporary, have thwarted the efforts of even the most enterprising and well-trainedexperts because much of this history is hidden, scattered or misplaced. And therein lies theopportunity and need that must be met. Because this history is hidden, residents andtourists alike fail to appreciate the fundamental role African Americans have played in thehistory of Essex County. In 2020, the two-year, grant-funded report, The African AmericanExperience in Essex County, Massachusetts: An Annotated Guide, was completed. Thepurpose of the report is to identify, locate, and compile the collections and resources,organizations, and individuals concerning the Black experience in Essex County. Our twoNational Park Service units in Essex County have sought to implement an inclusive,audience-centered interpretative approach that more prominently features the stories ofAfrican Americans. The report synthesizes key themes and offers suggestions for projectsand serves as a basis for developing historically sound, inclusive programming, fromexhibitions to school projects. African Americans and people of African descent stand tall inEssex County's past, present, and future. There are a wide range of stories and accounts ofBlack women in these collections and repositories. However, there is no singular "Blackwoman's” story to be told. The intern would work within a theme of the diverse ways inwhich Black women built lives, careers, and families, as well as fought for change, survivedand resisted oppression, and spoke out boldly for themselves and others. The intern willresearch African American women of Essex County who operated within and outside ofsystems that were intended to reduce or limit them; Black women who were leaders ineducation, in business, in civic life, in family life, in activism. The research will focus on boththe names that are well-known and the countless women whose names history hasforgotten, but who nevertheless built and fueled the culture of Essex County for generations.In the "Recommendations” section of the report, these are a few of the women suggested tobe researched: Charlotte Forten (Salem State University), Rose Lovejoy (Andover), FrancesCole Lee (Haverhill Public Library), Myrna Mitchell Brown (Lawrence), Sarah Remond (PhillipsLibrary), Juno Larcom (Historic Beverly), Agnes (Marblehead), and Sara Baro Colcher(Topsfield). While there are few complete collections of Black women's archival materials,African American women are not completely absent in the historical records. An exhibitcould make this explicit. Suggested ways an intern could tell the stories of the hundreds ofBlack women who have lived in Essex County who did not leave behind personal materials inthe archives include:
Using names from Massachusetts Vital Records and selecting somefrom Essex County to trace through Marriage, Births, and Deaths;
telling the story of Blackwomen who had accounts at the Salem Savings Bank using the records available throughthe Salem State University Archives; and
giving voice to the stories of Black women who were incarcerated at Essex County Jail. The intern will be responsible for researching,planning, drafting, and proposing an exhibit for the Salem Armory Visitor Center that couldalso travel to historic sites and museums in Essex County. Qualifications The intern should ideally be working toward a graduate degree in history or a related field, and have course work, experience, or interest in African American history, public history, education, and/or interpretation. The intern must have strong oral and written communication skills and some experience in working in the archives and/or at museum/historic site settings. The intern should be able to work independently 75% of the time. The intern should be someone who has experience and/or interest in developing an inclusive, audience-centered approach to education and interpretation that more prominently features and centers the stories of African American women.

Participants must be a U.S. citizen or U.S. permanent legal resident ( "green-card-holder) and currently enrolled in an undergraduate, graduate, or Ph.D. degree program at an accredited institution of higher education during the summer internship.

Additional Qualifications

Completion of quality secondary education
